title: Will legislation removing the individual mandate to purchase health insurance be signed before 30 April 2017?
preds: With 2 days left, and government funding a priority on the legislative agenda, I'm lowering my forecast to a 0% probability.

It's an attack on Conservative values. They don't want it to slowly disappear. They want the ACA to either crash-and-burn or be legislatively executed.

With the failure of the Paul Ryan health care bill, chances seem quite low that there will be removal of the mandate before April 30.  The mandate helps create a bigger risk pool of younger, healthier individuals that help health insurance companies pay the bills of sicker, older customers. The health insurance industry wanted the mandate in the first place, and wants it now. Health insurance industry profit is a big issue at the heart of the U.S. health-care and health-insurance systems (or non-systems). (I worked in the health care industry for 16 years, including during the launch of the ACA. Our company employees were briefed and trained extensively about the dynamics involved.) Given the amount of concern by Senate and House R's regarding  AHCA, and the uncompromising position by the Freedom Caucus, it seems unlikely that the GOP will be able to pass such legislation. While the use of reconciliation provides a vehicle for the GOP to do so, it also is limited in scope to funding issues. The individual mandate is arguably more of a policy decision than a funding decision, and the GOP may be in violation of procedural rules to pursue its removal via reconciliation. Additionally, if the GOP follows through on making the AHCA a requirement for passing the FY17 budget, it will likely fail, as Senate D's indicated they will force a government shutdown. With several R's also having serious doubts about the AHCA, this seems unlikely to proceed. However, the GOP has 4 weeks remaining in session to find a more palatable alternative, so there still remains a possibility that they could achieve this outcome.

And then it's off to conference committee unless the Senate passes the House version, which never happens.   It is very tricky to repeal a complex piece of existing legislation and then replace it with something that doesn't change it very much. The Republicans have made quite a fine mess of the mess left by the Democrats, who failed to grasp the mess that is the United States health care market(s); and I use that term ("mess") in the technical, Ackoffian sort of way. By focusing on second-order symptoms (the insurance market) they have neglected the underlying causes (cost; i.e., the supply/demand market). And, while of course there are inter-dependencies between the two, our "professional" politicians, and their "professional" (bureaucratic) staff are so far out of their league on this we simply have to recognize that some political decisions are too significant to be left up to politicians. [Attn: @cdob63] Nary a discussion of enhanced early childhood/developmental (preventative) care, better health education, more doctors, governmental bidding on prescription drugs, standard testing protocols for specific diseases, elimination of intermediaries to the intermediaries to the intermediaries, quality outcome statistics for informed patient decision-making, and the plethora of other things that might be implemented to lower costs across the board and increase market competitiveness, all while enhancing quality. In addition, there needs to be some adult discussion about the exceedingly high costs associated with battling "terminal" and geriatric end-of-life conditions and where the equity for such costs lay (who should bear them, and to what extent).

In the face of opposition by Democrats, healthcare providers and many conservatives, two House of Representatives committees approved the legislation that would undo much of the 2010 Affordable Care Act, popularly known as Obamacare, moving it closer to a vote before the full House. The Energy and Commerce Committee voted 31-23 along party lines, with Democrats unified against it, to back the plan after marathon proceedings lasting 27 straight hours. Hours earlier, the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee similarly voted 23-16 before dawn to approve it after working 17 straight hours. The House Budget Committee next Wednesday is due to merge the provisions approved by the two committees into one bill to be voted on by the full House before it goes to the Senate. Reasons for repeal of individual mandate occurring by April 30th:
* Republican representatives and senators have opposed the mandate and ACA for years. Trump has promised to repeal it.  
* Republicans who do not vote to repeal this part or the full ACA risk facing primary challengers. I think most Republicans believe the risk of losing in a primary is greater than losing in a general election.
* It might be difficult for Democrats to muster enough votes to block changes to this through a filibuster.
* Targeting one less popular aspect of the bill is easier than trying to repeal and replace the full ACA. Reasons against repeal of individual mandate occurring by April 30th:
* Republicans have not yet decided on a plan to replace ACA (though there are multiple plans/outlines under consideration).
* Congress does not seem to have accomplished much so far, and could be tied up with other events and legislation.
* While it may be easy to target the mandate, several conservative Republicans have insisted that the ACA be completely repealed as opposed to taking a piecemeal approach. 
* The program is more popular now, and supporters are organized. While this would not have much impact on very conservative Republicans in safe districts, moderate Republicans, especially in the Senate, may face pressure at town hall meetings. 
* It is very difficult to change just one aspect of the ACA without adverse consequences. Repealing just the mandate could cause premiums to rise, and Republicans would likely be blamed.

Contra many of the comments on this question so far, the ball isn't really in Pres. Trump's court. So any bets about whether or not legislation will be signed (Pres. Trump is almost certain to sign such a bill) are actually bets about whether Congress will pass such legislation prior to the end of the hundred days. However, it seems as though Congressional Republicans are only just now engaging with the questions of how this will affect the country, and how to mitigate damage with a more conservative approach. That increases my degree of uncertainty about their ability to pass such legislation. There aren't any meaningful, hard time constraints. Presently, I feel very confidently that they'll repeal the individual mandate within Pres. Trump's first term, but much less so that they'll accomplish it within the first hundred days without an actual institutional constraint.
To formalize this, I'll assign a .99 probability to a legislative dismantling of the ACA within Trump's first term. If we break that term into three-month blocks (resembling the roughly three months between now and the end of the hundred days), Congress has 16 discrete time steps in which to pass a repeal. If we treat repeal as an independent event occurring in one of the blocks, each one has a roughly 25% of seeing the repeal. Moreover, Congress' incentive to pass a repeal will follow a U-shaped curve over time: as we move away from the inauguration, doing it soon will seem less important. However, as we approach the 2020 election, it will become considerably more urgent.
If it appears that congressional Republicans begin coalescing around a single plan, either to replace or simply to repeal and then figure out what to build in its place (or do nothing), I will scrap this model in favor of one which more closely matches my internal assessment of their determination to actually repeal the law.

NYTimes lists benefits repeal of the ACA may end:
1) Over 55: ACA limits premiums now limited at 3 times premiums for younger people.  PRyan to raise to 5 times.
2) Men and women pay same premium under ACA.  Before ACA women paid more (up to 50% more).
3) ACA added coverage for: treatment for addiction (to 30% of uninsured policies), and mental health (added to 20% of non covered policies).
4) Before ACA 50% of employer health plans capped annual and lifetime payments, many between 1 and 2 million.  Mini med plans were often capped at a few thousand dollars per year.  (This is one reason why ACA didn't want you to keep your old plan).
5) Before ACA 130 million Americans were in high risk pools with high premiums.
6) ACA capped out of pocket expenses at $7,150 for individuals and 14,300 for families.
7) 12 million gained health insurance under ACA.

The Individual Mandate requires those without any health coverage  acquire health coverage, (A) via state exchanges that offer coverage under ACA. (B) purchase private coverage, (C) have coverage provided by an employer.  (D) eligibility for coverage under Medicaid. By not having any of the (4) options for coverage a tax penalty is applied to the non-insured tax payer. Legislation before April 30 is not necessary because, (A) the elimination of the tax penalty will not apply until April 15, 2018. I am assuming the GOP is highly motivated to start work on dismantling "Obamacare" so i give a 100% change that such legislation will be introduced.  In 2015 there was an attempt to repeal part of the law including the individual mandate which was vetoed by the President.  Sponsors of the repeal legislation used a provision of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 called reconciliation that allows for expedited consideration of such legislation.  Speaker Ryan has suggested use of the process again to minimize Democratic resistance to the passage of the legislation.  All twenty four times a reconciliation bill has been attempted it has been successful, though in 4 cases the President vetoed the Bill.  The time for a reconciliation bill to wind its way through Congress ranges from 27 days to 384 days, with an average of 155 days.  The 2015 Bill took 248 days.  In 11 of the 24 cases has the legislation been able to get through the process in fewer than 120 days, so I think the likelihood  of passage within the first 120 days of 2017 is 46%

I worked in the health insurance business for 16 years. The so-called "individual mandate" required all people to have health insurance or face a fine. This was one of the more disliked elements of the Affordable Care Act (ACA) but was wanted by the health insurance industry and health insurance experts because a bigger pool of insured persons is reported to be more financially viable.  Younger, healthier people who don't have huge health-care costs (yet) basically subsidize older people and those with expensive health situations. It was portrayed as -- and many people felt it was -- a government intrusion on their freedom (even though we are required to carry car insurance too). So, even though there was a logical reason for the individual mandate, it would be fairly painless politically, and probably politically popular to alter it or dump it as part of other changes.

The larger number of people signing up this year before the new administration takes office suggests that there is a strong popular belief that steps will be taken to dismantle the ACA, of which removing the mandate is a part.  Since these people are putting their money where their mouths are, they are worth paying attention to.  In addition, since there will be limited direct consequences until the next signup period, this step will be relatively costless for the new administration and thus more likely to be taken.  There has also been much discussion of delays in dismantling the ACA - pass legislation but do not put it into effect until some future date (such as after the next midterms).  That possibility muddies what may actually happen.  New administration will want to rack up lots to claim credit for early but will be much less willing to commit to much of consequence.
